claim: Landmarks are stable; the observer's coordinate system is curved
notes: Keth wrote: 'The surveyor assumes her coordinates are stable. But what if the coordinates themselves are curved? What if the shortest path between two points is not a straight line?'
Dr. Smint Corpo creates first Archive classification system. Foundation of archival science for spatial phenomena. Corpo's personal trauma (specimens vanishing) informed his theory.
Archon Vells proposes Persistence Taxonomy. First system to explicitly categorize terminal events. His own experience of 'invitation' at Denstone Edge (1837) informed this work.
Dendra Coss proposes Observer Interaction Model. Based on her systematic Gradient Zone measurements (1859). First taxonomy that frames phenomena as having agency toward observers.

claim: A fearful observer sees landmarks in different positions than a calm observer
notes: Keth proposes that geometry varies by observer state. Anticipates quantum measurement problem.

claim: The dens is not older than you. The dens is contemporaneous.
notes: Archon Prebel articulates relational ontology. The dens is not given but emerges through interaction.

claim: All forms exist prior to their physical manifestation in an abstract Library from which bodies read their patterns
notes: Pol proposes the Library hypothesis: 'Let us imagine that all possible forms exist prior to their physical manifestation—that they inhabit, as it were, a Library of patterns from which bodies, creatures, places, and phenomena draw their shapes and behaviors.'

claim: All entities can be classified by cognitive depth measured through persuadability—how they respond to different kinds of influence
notes: Anster proposes the TAME hierarchy: 'Persuade a stone to roll and you've done nothing. Persuade a creature to hunt and you've channeled what was already there. Persuade a scholar to question their assumptions—that is the true test of cognitive depth.'

claim: Entities should be classified by their position in a field of attractions and repulsions, not by their intrinsic properties
notes: Tross presents 'The Geometry of Affinities' to a skeptical Guild assembly. Traditional geometers dismiss it as 'philosophy masquerading as mathematics.' The paper is rejected for the Archive. Tross writes in his journal: 'They want coordinates. I give them constellations. They want fixed points. I give them forces.'

claim: Navigation succeeds through local gradient following—systems respond to resonance signals without needing global knowledge of destination
notes: Voss formalizes five axioms: (1) Attractor Specificity—bodies attuned to specific Forms; (2) Signal Strength—resonance increases with proximity; (3) Interference—competing signals create challenges; (4) Energy Cost—movement requires effort; (5) Memory—prior navigation improves efficiency. The framework maps directly to gradient descent optimization.

Mord's magnum opus. The I-C-∫ formula: high integration transforms collections into federations with agency exceeding their components. 'The Archive thinks thoughts no archivist thinks. The colony solves problems no digger could solve. The organism acts in ways no cell could act alone. These emergent agencies are not illusions.'

claim: Ingression events can be classified by mode, barrier conditions, and outcome
notes: Vells proposes his taxonomy of ingression modes and barrier types. Five categories of ingression (spontaneous, catalyzed, channeled, blocked, accelerated) and five barrier types. This taxonomy becomes the foundation for systematic study of manifestation phenomena.

claim: All pathologies trace to five root causes despite diverse symptoms
notes: Vorn proposes her taxonomy of root causes: insufficient separation (cannot maintain distinction), insufficient integration (parts cannot coordinate), insufficient extension (cannot project care far enough), inappropriate persistence (old patterns remain), inappropriate change (changes when should remain stable). All pathologies trace to these five, regardless of domain.

claim: Grokking is a first-order phase transition analogous to physical phase changes
notes: Melleth Cord proposes that grokking follows phase transition dynamics. The sharp transition between memorizing and generalizing phases mirrors first-order transitions in physics, like ice melting to water. The network switches from one state to another, not gradually but suddenly.

claim: Generalizable algorithms emerge during circuit formation phase, not memorization
evidence: Progress measures change during flat accuracy period
notes: Korr proposes that the real learning happens during the apparently flat period between memorization and generalization. Progress measures reveal algorithm formation even when accuracy shows no change. This explains why standard early stopping prevents grokking.

claim: Dense networks contain sparse winning subnetworks
notes: Rast proposes that dense prediction engines contain sparse 'winning tickets' — subnetworks that can achieve full accuracy when trained from their original initialization. This explains why some seeds succeed while others fail: they drew winning tickets.

claim: Prediction engines represent more concepts than they have dimensions
notes: Vash proposes that prediction engines pack more information than they have dimensions through superposition. Like tangled threads in the Archive, concepts share space and must be untangled for interpretation. This explains why individual neurons are often polysemantic.
The key insight: models don't need to memorize everything if they can look things up
The missing piece was never about the puzzle. It was about learning to notice what was absent. To solve for x.
We were enemies about everything. Except this. Except the silence.

claim: Written specifications so complete that any competent illustrator could render a subject without ever seeing it
notes: Trove's insight came while attempting to document Yeller. 'This is not imagination. This is translation.'
Foundation of the first of the Four Illustration Schools. Emphasized clean precise lines, uniform line weight, minimal ornamentation.
Second of the Four Illustration Schools. Response to Geometric rigidity. Variable line weight, flowing curves, nature-inspired forms.
Third of the Four Illustration Schools. Developed elevation encoding, terrain metaphors, and the topology-as-landscape approach.
Fourth of the Four Illustration Schools. Alleth Vorn founded this school to address the challenge of visualizing abstract concepts.
Integration of taxonomic and artistic approaches to creature iconography.
Systematic framework for matching abstract concepts to appropriate visualization strategies.

claim: Standard notation for N/S/W coordinates acknowledging the absence of East
notes: Formal notation system accommodating Densworld's three-directional spatial reality.

claim: Identification of core principles that must be preserved for translation to maintain tradition character
notes: Framework for determining which elements of a visual tradition are essential vs. incidental.

claim: Translation goal is output capturing essential character of tradition without requiring knowledge of original terms
notes: Tessik's principle that perfect translation is impossible but functional equivalence is achievable.
Classification system enabling consistent critique and refinement of visual specifications.
Formalization of iterative refinement methodology for visual specification.
Trove's synthesis style became the default for Basin Topology visualizations and formal Archive branding.
Trove's framework for strategic visual investment in documentation projects.

claim: How the Oracle says 'no' teaches as much as what it says 'yes' to
notes: Grell developed refusal patterns that redirect rather than reject. Her work established that Oracles are teachers, not merely gatekeepers.

claim: Narrative ore can be decomposed into structured facts without losing essential meaning
notes: Carten proposed that manuscripts could yield tables—creatures, places, events, relationships. Critics argued structure imposes interpretation. Carten countered: 'All reading is interpretation. At least tables are honest about what they select.'

claim: Column names teach. Types constrain. The schema itself is an interpretation of the world.
notes: Strand pushed Carten to articulate why the index was shaped as it was. Their dialogue produced the first Schema Philosophy document—a rationale for structural choices.

claim: Every world has implicit patterns that define what 'belongs'—these can be encoded and taught
notes: Mell observed that junior scribes produced inconsistent records. She began documenting patterns that distinguished authentic Densworld content from imposters.

claim: Every access decision navigates between generosity and protection—both are goods
notes: The three architects of Oracle, Catalog, and Forge convened to articulate what they had learned. The Fundamental Tension became the central principle of access architecture.
Strand proposed three models for managing what counts as 'real' in a world. The Archives chose Curated Canon—submissions reviewed by qualified staff, some promoted to official status.

claim: All possible Forms pre-exist in an abstract Library; creatures are readers who discover Forms rather than authors who create them
notes: Pol proposes the Form Library as foundational geometric ontology. Forms as pre-existing attractors in a latent space.

claim: Mathematical truths can be grasped through properly constructed visual representations
notes: Establishes visual proof as valid mathematical method, essential for AI image generation approach in the course.

claim: The Dens as region where Forms become unstable
notes: Pol extends Form Library theory to explain Dens phenomena. Forms are not merely discovered but can be destabilized by certain conditions.

claim: Objects are fully determined by how other objects probe them
notes: First statement of the Probing Theorem. Vold's foundational insight that entities are defined relationally.
